author: celebricat
title: Why we need to stop asking women if they are pregnant
text:
There should be a special circle in hell reserved for people who point at your stomach and ask if you are pregnant. 
I’m not talking about the close friends and relatives who may pull you aside and ask you discreetly.
Get out of the gym – why we need to stop body shaming people exercising I am talking about the strangers in the supermarkets and shops, or random acquaintances, who stand and point at your stomach and loudly ask, ‘Are you pregnant?’
It could be a variation of this question, like when’s it due or what are you having.
If you are not pregnant, it is very much a ground-swallow-me-up-now moment as you struggle to find the words to explain to a perfect stranger that it is very much just a food baby under your jumper.
Please stop asking (Picture: Mmuffin for Metro.co.uk) A friend revealed on Facebook that this had happened to her, and out came the stories from other women who had been asked if they were pregnant – usually by men.
And it has happened to me too.
Can we just f***ing stop asking couples when they’re going to have a baby? I bumped into someone I knew vaguely while in Boots, who asked, ‘Is [my then boyfriend now husband] the father of that one?’
(Who even asks that?)
Yes, I told him.
His accusatory finger then pointed towards my midriff, ‘Is he the father of that one too?’
I wanted the ground to open up in the hair colourant aisle and swallow me whole.
At the very least, I was going to chuck my floral Topshop top straight into the bin.
(Picture: Mmuffin for Metro.co.uk) After I told him that, no, I wasn’t incubating a small person in my womb, that this was just pure fat, his female friend burst out laughing like it was hilarious rather than toe-curlingly excruciating.
Cheers sister.
Look, if a woman is happy for you to know she is pregnant, she will tell you.
Ask how she is, what has she been up to, or something like that and, if she wants to mention it, she will.
She will say they are excitedly waiting for their first child, she will moan about the aches and pains of pregnancies or tell you about the many appointments she has had.
But if she isn’t, you will just leave her feeling like crap.
She might not even want a baby (Picture: Liberty Antonia Sadler for Metro.co.uk) You don’t know whether she has been trying and it hasn’t happened yet, or struggling to drop the weight from the previous baby .
And even if she is pregnant , there may be a million and one reasons why she doesn’t want to tell a complete stranger or someone she only met once on a course five years ago.

Perhaps she hasn’t reached the all-important 12 week stage, perhaps she hasn’t told her nearest and dearest yet, perhaps she has had a miscarriage or this is a rainbow baby or the pregnancy has been a tough one.
It’s just damn rude and insensitive to ask.
Just bite your tongue and avoid looking like a total douchebag by putting your feet in it.
If you’re struggling for a conversation topic with a stranger, try the weather.
